subNodes.conversationText: root
"Retreat! Retreat!" cried the witch hunter. "This witch is deadly."
[Continue.]
The command was unnecessary: almost everyone had fallen back. Mnesse stood her ground, though, and wiped blood from her mouth.
"We have no reason to fight," responded <FirstName>.
"I don't know what I was thinking. The feast wasn't here. It was somewhere else. We have to find it."
[Continue.]
"The witch and <his/her> gourd friend chased everyone else off, Mnesse. Maybe you should look for them first," said Phaedrus.
[Continue.]

"Maybe."

Mnesse and <FirstName> gazed at each other curiously. They were a striking pair -- the magician in her tattered robes, the witch in <his/her> equally tattered garments, each hunting mysterious quarries.
[Continue.]
"Mind your own business. Don't follow us. Watch yourself -- we'll be better prepared for you next time."
"I hope so. You couldn't be any worse prepared."
"And you couldn't be any luckier to have caught me off guard." Then she turned away.
[Continue.]
She glided into the woods, her feet a few inches above the forest floor. The rest of the band scattered. The witch hunter ran fastest.
"I don't know who Zaurus is! I've never heard of him!" <FirstName> called after the magician.

"I'm going back to the inn!" Phaedrus called after her. She didn't turn around.

He sighed, grimaced at <FirstName>, and sprang into the woods.

He had not been dead long. His clothes were soaked with blood. It did look like the work of redcaps -- certainly not a witch, as the witch hunter had posited. A silver ring he wore caught the witch's interest. <He/She> recognized it a the token of a guardian spirit, a tutelar. Such trinkets were common among travelers.
"Looks like your spirit was playing truant."
The ring glittered.
<He/She> tried to take it.

It was hard to get off. The man's fingers were fat. The young witch had to grab his wrist with one hand and pull hard, and even then the ring didn't budge. The pained expression on the corpse's face disturbed <him/her>.
<He/She> ignored the temptation.
<He/She> had Knott roll the body into the woods. The crow pestered the gourd while he worked.
<FirstName> tried to take the ring.

It was hard to get off. The man's fingers were fat. The young witch had to grab his wrist with one hand and pull hard, and even then the ring didn't budge. The pained expression on the corpse's face disturbed <him/her>.
<He/She> kept trying.
At last the ring came off. <FirstName> pocketed it.
[Continue.]
<He/She> had Knott roll the body into the woods. The crow pestered the gourd while he worked.
Then they continued on.

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Magician

The witch encountered a small company that included a magician and her escort, one of whom was a witch hunter. The magician, a woman named Mnesse, seemed to be hunting for someone named Zaurus. After the young witch defeated them in battle, Mnesse retreated, once again mentioning Zaurus.

subNodes.conversationText: <FirstName> left the ring alone.
<FirstName> left the ring alone.
<He/She> had Knott roll the body into the woods. The crow pestered the gourd while he worked.
[Continue.]
The body Mnesse and Palamon had been discussing was still there. Pharaoh hopped alongside it while keeping an eye on <FirstName>.
<FirstName> examined it.

He had not been dead long. His clothes were soaked with blood. It did look like the work of redcaps -- certainly not a witch, as the witch hunter had posited. A silver ring he wore caught the witch's interest. <He/She> recognized it a the token of a guardian spirit, a tutelar. Such trinkets were common among travelers.
"Leave it alone, Pharaoh. Let's go."
<He/She> had Knott roll the body into the woods. The crow pestered the gourd while he worked.
"I don't know who Zaurus is! I've never heard of him!" <FirstName> cried after the magician.
The body Mnesse and Palamon had been discussing was still there. Pharaoh hopped alongside it while keeping an eye on <FirstName>.
<FirstName> watched them go in silence.
The body Mnesse and Palamon had been discussing was still there. Pharaoh hopped alongside it while keeping an eye on <FirstName>.
"Next time? I didn't want to fight you. You forced my hand."
"Forced? I didn't know witches could be forced to do anything."
[Continue.]
"Let's hear <him/her> out, Mnesse. We have too many enemies as it is."
[Continue.]
"Who are you? What are you after?"
"If I knew for sure, I probably wouldn't be after it." Then she turned away.
[Continue.]
"We have no reason to fight," <FirstName> said to her.
"Do not listen! Stuff cotton in your ears. <He/She> will charm you."
[Continue.]
"Or kill you. But <he/she> could have done that already. I say we see what <he/she> has to say."
[Continue.]

"No, Palamon! 's a witch. is the enemy. Zaurus sought the devil's protection in these woods, and the coven was happy to oblige -- For the witch gives good things to the wicked, and wicked things to the good."
[Continue.]

"It's possible," mused Mnesse.

She and <FirstName> gazed at each other. They were a striking pair -- the magician in her tattered robes, the witch in <his/her> equally tattered garments, each hunting mysterious quarries.

Then the magician turned away.
[Continue.]
"You forced my hand. Don't force it again."
"Forced? I didn't know witches could be forced to do anything."
